Is this true? Have protons replaced photons in IMRT?

subs.text: July 19

Nassim Taleb is a tough act to follow, but this 90-minute primer on covid was A+. A tiny quibble (I have to, I’m sorry): A.F. discouraging mask use was more a misguided attempt to manage the shortage than an evidence-based rec. Backfired, obviously. [link]

subs.text: @otrasenda_AC @NahanniFinanci1 @nntaleb @GGCanto Hm, not sure how the fence paradox would apply to lanes… Cyclists and/or drivers becoming less careful/not aggressive because of the separation? Is there data to suggest it going one way or the other (same city before/after lanes, or otherwise similar cities with/without)?

subs.text:
@otrasenda_AC @NahanniFinanci1 @nntaleb @GGCanto Not=more (typo).
There are many plausible narratives for why lanes would be good or bad, but this reminds me of some saying in spring 2020 that masks may *increase* infections because of false sense of security. Well, sure, possible but unlikely, so let’s look at the data.
subs.rawText:
@otrasenda_AC @NahanniFinanci1 @nntaleb @GGCanto Not=more (typo).
There are many plausible narratives for why lanes would be good or bad, but this reminds me of some saying in spring 2020 that masks may *increase* infections because of false sense of security. Well, sure, possible but unlikely, so let’s look at the data.

subs.text: @eliowa Excellent point. Another one is: how does this compare to other viruses? SARS-CoV-1? Endemic coronaviruses? Adeno or rhinoviruses? EBV? There is so much opportunity here to learn about viral effects and prevention in general that we are missing because of hyperfocus on covid.
subs.rawText: @eliowa Excellent point. Another one is: how does this compare to other viruses? SARS-CoV-1? Endemic coronaviruses? Adeno or rhinoviruses? EBV? There is so much opportunity here to learn about viral effects and prevention in general that we are missing because of hyperfocus on covid.

subs.text: @nntaleb @GGCanto Yep, bike lanes are still key, with or without pedal assist. DC has smartly put them in quieter side streets. That way you only need to worry about drunk restaurant patrons, not so much cars. [link]

subs.text: CDC community transmission map for the last month. BA.5 was 9.6% on 6/4 and became the dominant strain at 53.5% on 7/2, per [link]. So, unless the CDC changes category thresholds or adds a purple “ultra high” category this won’t tell us anything about BA.5. https://t.co/H8OKWNjnNl
subs.rawText:
CDC community transmission map for the last month. BA.5 was 9.6% on 6/4 and became the dominant strain at 53.5% on 7/2, per https://t.co/ff7GEt7VOj.

subs.text: @tmprowell @trishankkarthik For a while now the likelihood of infection without precautions has been 100%, conditional on not dying of other causes. To be clear, that’s terrible and was completely avoidable (though hard to say when we crossed the threshold). So in that sense, aren’t levels more informative?
subs.rawText: @tmprowell @trishankkarthik For a while now the likelihood of infection without precautions has been 100%, conditional on not dying of other causes. To be clear, that’s terrible and was completely avoidable (though hard to say when we crossed the threshold). So in that sense, aren’t levels more informative?

subs.text: @tmprowell @trishankkarthik To that effect, here is the time lapse of the past month for covid *transmission* levels. BA.5 didn't become dominant until 7/2 per CDC ([link]) and was <10% when the time lapse started so how much more information can we get out of transmission alone? https://t.co/royAsX9zbx
subs.rawText: @tmprowell @trishankkarthik To that effect, here is the time lapse of the past month for covid *transmission* levels. BA.5 didn't become dominant until 7/2 per CDC (https://t.co/ff7GEt7VOj) and was <10% when the time lapse started so how much more information can we get out of transmission alone? https://t.co/royAsX9zbx

subs.text: @trishankkarthik @EricTopol To be more specific: the claim "reinfections may be more severe" is correct. They *may*. But there is a wide chasm between that statement and claims made in the Forever Plague article, and there is some evidence that refutes those claims that should have been at least mentioned.
subs.rawText: @trishankkarthik @EricTopol To be more specific: the claim "reinfections may be more severe" is correct. They *may*. But there is a wide chasm between that statement and claims made in the Forever Plague article, and there is some evidence that refutes those claims that should have been at least mentioned.

subs.text: @tmprowell Please see my response.
subs.rawText: @tmprowell Please see my response.

subs.text: @tmprowell @trishankkarthik Got it! Your tweet was about community levels though, not transmission, which is what got me confused. Apologies for getting that part wrong!!! Still, good practice to have date+source on any graph, for this reason.
subs.rawText: @tmprowell @trishankkarthik Got it! Your tweet was about community levels though, not transmission, which is what got me confused. Apologies for getting that part wrong!!! Still, good practice to have date+source on any graph, for this reason.

subs.text: 📚 Catching up with John, the busted high-yield trader in Fooled by Randomness. If you are talking about a 10 sigma event you should have thought in alphas, not sigmas. There may be early hints that the data is not Gaussian but people call them outliers and brush them away. [link]
subs.rawText:
📚 Catching up with John, the busted high-yield trader in Fooled by Randomness.

If you are talking about a 10 sigma event you should have thought in alphas, not sigmas. There may be early hints that the data is not Gaussian but people call them outliers and brush them away. https://t.co/9dS3tchf95

subs.text: @GuruAnaerobic Ok, what is your (or someone else’s, I don’t care) best argument for why lockdowns in March 2020 weren’t justified ex ante? Because the only thing I’ve seen so far is people using ex post (bad) or disputing the whole ex ante/ex post distinction (worse).
subs.rawText: @GuruAnaerobic Ok, what is your (or someone else’s, I don’t care) best argument for why lockdowns in March 2020 weren’t justified ex ante? Because the only thing I’ve seen so far is people using ex post (bad) or disputing the whole ex ante/ex post distinction (worse).

subs.text: @TeaRespecter To clarify: are you saying that these comparisons (and let’s not go into how well they were made) can be used to assess wether or not the March 2020 lockdowns (not the later ones) were justified?
subs.rawText: @TeaRespecter To clarify: are you saying that these comparisons (and let’s not go into how well they were made) can be used to assess wether or not the March 2020 lockdowns (not the later ones) were justified?

subs.text: @billmceachern Hard to argue with that (and any nuances between fall 2020 versus 2021 are beyond Twitter to convey).
subs.rawText: @billmceachern Hard to argue with that (and any nuances between fall 2020 versus 2021 are beyond Twitter to convey).

subs.text: @TeaRespecter Yes, they are evaluating them ex post, and badly at that.

subs.text: 📚 Fooled by hindsight bias. This one is for anyone who thinks lockdowns and school closures in the spring of 2020 were a mistake. Making ex post “predictions” is infinitely easier than ex ante, and gives you a false sense of confidence to boot. Dangerous and stupid. [link]
subs.rawText:
📚 Fooled by hindsight bias. This one is for anyone who thinks lockdowns and school closures in the spring of 2020 were a mistake.

Making ex post “predictions” is infinitely easier than ex ante, and gives you a false sense of confidence to boot. Dangerous and stupid. https://t.co/q5yHrHQ4zy

subs.text: The excerpt is from Fooled by Randomness by Nassim Taleb, paperback edition (2005).
subs.rawText: The excerpt is from Fooled by Randomness by Nassim Taleb, paperback edition (2005).

subs.text: Several imprecisions in this essay on IRBs should not detract from its key point: social sciences don’t need IRB oversight, biomedicine needs it to be less byzantine and more transparent. Status quo is untenable. [link]
subs.rawText: Several imprecisions in this essay on IRBs should not detract from its key point: social sciences don’t need IRB oversight, biomedicine needs it to be less byzantine and more transparent. Status quo is untenable. https://t.co/ovrddHZBFT

subs.text: 📚 Taleb the prophet, writing about cryptobros and the summer of 2022 back in the early 2000s. Financial instruments come and go but human stupidity and greed are forever. [link]

subs.text: July 1

Give a lecture once and you help a few hundred people (if you’re lucky). Post the lecture to YouTube and you help millions. 7 years later, I am yet to find a better guide to academic writing. NB: it’s good to have a live audience. [link]
subs.rawText:
Give a lecture once and you help a few hundred people (if you’re lucky). Post the lecture to YouTube and you help millions. 7 years later, I am yet to find a better guide to academic writing.

NB: it’s good to have a live audience. https://t.co/7PhQt2RTRA
